content.text: ''CSI,'' on CBS, came within a half million viewers of ABC's ''Grey's Anatomy'' on Thursday night at 9. According to Nielsen's estimates, ''CSI'' drew just under 21 million viewers, to 21.4 million for ''Grey's Anatomy.'' CBS finished No. 1 for the night in total viewers, but ABC dominated among adults 18 to 49. At 8, a rebroadcast of CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' (12.4 million) finished first ahead of ABC's ''Ugly Betty'' (9.8 million), which posted its best ratings for a rerun. A rerun of CBS's ''Shark'' (14 million) led at 10 in total viewers, while ABC's ''Men in Trees'' (11 million) edged it out among adults 18 to 49, posting a series high in that demographic. NBC was third for the night with a lineup of comedy reruns from 8 to 11. ''My Name Is Earl'' at 8 (8.4 million) and ''The Office'' at 8:30 (7.8 million), led at 8 among adults 18 to 49.  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; Cops Vs. Docs

content.text: ''Grey's Anatomy'' outdrew its 9 p.m. competition on Thursday on CBS, NBC and Fox combined, as ABC went on to dominate the night over all. According to Nielsen's estimates, this medical drama drew 22.9 million viewers, its second-largest audience since September. ABC also led in total viewers at 8 p.m. with ''Ugly Betty'' (13.4 million), while at 10, ''Men in Trees'' (10.3 million) edged out a repeat of CBS's ''Shark'' (10.2 million) to finish second behind NBC's ''ER'' (12.1 million). Among adults 18 to 49, NBC ranked No. 2 for the night, thanks to ''My Name Is Earl'' at 8 (10.9 million) and ''The Office'' at 8:30 (10.2 million).  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; 'Grey' Leads for ABC

content.text: The addition of Liev Schreiber to the cast of ''CSI'' helped give CBS the top spot Thursday night, but ''Ugly Betty'' and ''Grey's Anatomy,'' which both won Golden Globes on Monday, put ABC on top among adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsen's estimates, 21.3 million viewers tuned in at 9 p.m. for ''CSI,'' ranking it just behind ''Grey's Anatomy,'' which had 21.9 million viewers in the same time slot. CBS led during the 10 p.m. hour opposite a repeat of NBC's ''ER'' (6.1 million), as ''Shark'' (15 million) matched its season's best ratings in the 18 to 49 demographic. ABC's ''Ugly Betty'' drew the most total viewers (14.1 million) at 8, while the lead in the 18-to-49 demographic went to NBC's ''My Name Is Earl'' at 8 (9.7 million) and ''The Office'' at 8:30 (9.3 million). NBC, with ''Scrubs'' at 9 (6.6 million) and ''30 Rock'' at 9:30 (5.1 million), was third for the night.  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; 'CSI' vs. 'Grey's Anatomy'

content.text: Opposite postseason football on Fox and a new episode of ''Desperate Housewives'' on ABC, two reality shows on NBC made their debuts Sunday to lukewarm ratings. According to Nielsen's estimates, the sixth edition of the Donald Trump series, ''The Apprentice,'' relocated from New York to Los Angeles, earned 9.1 million viewers from 9:30 to 11 p.m., about even with February's premiere of ''The Apprentice 5.'' NBC fared slightly better earlier in the night, as its musical competition, ''Grease: You're the One That I Want,'' averaged 11.6 million viewers from 8 to 9:30. NBC ranked fourth for the night in total viewers, but third among adults 18 to 49. Fox led over all, benefiting from an overrun of its afternoon coverage of the Philadelphia Eagles victory over the New York Giants. ABC was No. 2 for the night, winning the 8 and 9 p.m. hours with ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' (13.4 million) and ''Desperate Housewives'' (18.6 million). CBS, which broadcast new episodes of ''Cold Case'' at 9 (14.1 million) and ''Without a Trace'' at 10 (14.2 million), finished the night in fourth among adults 18 to 49, but ahead of NBC in total viewers.  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; Ho-Hum Debuts for NBC

content.text: An article in The Arts last Wednesday about NBC's plans to extend the ''Today'' program to a fourth hour attributed an erroneous distinction to the show. ''Nightwatch'' on CBS, which had its premiere in 1982, ran for four hours on weekdays. ''Today'' will not be the first such weekday program of that length on major broadcast networks.
content.title: Corrections

content.text: An obituary on Jan. 19 about Ron Carey, a comic actor, referred incorrectly to the character he played on the situation comedy ''Barney Miller.'' He was a uniformed policeman, not a ''plainclothes cop.'' The obituary also included an outdated title for a television show that Mr. Carey appeared on in 1969 and 1970. By that time, it was known as ''The Ed Sullivan Show,'' not ''Toast of the Town.''
content.title: Corrections

content.text: A television review on Jan. 2 about ''Dirt,'' on FX, referred incorrectly to the channel. It is a basic cable channel, not a premium one.
content.title: Corrections

content.text: A picture with a Collecting article last Sunday about Aston Martin was published in error. While a 1961 Aston Martin DB4 GT Zagato, described in the article as one of the most charismatic sports cars of the 1960s, was indeed depicted in a front view, the car shown in profile was not a Zagato, but a GT with a conventional body.
content.title: Correction

content.text: Football once again reigned in the ratings on Wednesday, as Fox's coverage of the Sugar Bowl led the night in every half-hour, according to Nielsen's estimates. In the race for No. 2, CBS outdrew NBC, and both networks overshadowed the premieres on ABC. CBS's only new show of the night, ''The King of Queens,'' ranked second at 8 p.m. with 8.6 million viewers. It was followed by repeats of ''Two and a Half Men'' at 8:30 (8.5 million), ''Criminals Minds'' at 9 (11.9 Million) and ''CSI: New York'' at 10 (10.4 million). NBC was not far behind, getting a boost from ''Deal or No Deal'' at 9 (11.3 million) and ''Medium'' at 10 (9.3 million). Faring less well for NBC, ''Friday Night Lights'' earned 6.3 million viewers at 8. ABC was last over all, despite the season premiere of ''According to Jim'' at 8 (7.4 million). Neither of ABC's new comedies, ''Knights of Prosperity'' at 9 (7.2 million) or ''In Case of Emergency'' at 9:30 (6.3 million), fared better than fourth place.  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; Sugar Bowl Victory for Fox

content.text: With its combination of ''Prison Break'' and ''24,'' Fox edged ahead of NBC on Monday to win the important demographic of adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsen's estimates, ''Prison Break'' matched a season's best 9.9 million viewers at 8 p.m., while the sixth hour of ''24'' earned 14 million viewers to lead the 9 p.m. hour in total viewers ahead of NBC's ''Heroes'' (13.6 million). ''Heroes'' did remain the night's highest-rated show in the 18 to 49 demographic, ahead of second-place ''24.'' For the night, NBC outdrew Fox by a half million total viewers. Its game show at 8, ''Deal or No Deal,'' claimed the title of most-watched show on Monday (16.9 million), but the 10 o'clock hour remained NBC's weakest, as ''Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip'' attracted 7 million viewers opposite a repeat of CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' (13.4 million). CBS broadcast reruns of its comedy lineup from 8 to 10 and finished third over all. ABC was fourth, despite new episodes of ''Supernanny'' at 9 (8.7 million) and ''What About Brian'' at 10 (5.7 million).  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; Fox and NBC Duke it Out

content.text: Two new ABC comedies failed to gain traction Wednesday, one week after making their debuts to modest ratings. Pushed back because of the live presidential address at 9 p.m., ''Knights of Prosperity'' drew 5.2 million viewers at about 9:30, according to Nielsen's estimates, while ''In Case of Emergency'' reached 5.8 million at 10. ABC did lead the 8 p.m. hour in total viewers with two episodes of ''According to Jim'' at 8 (8.3 million) and 8:30 (8.8 million). ABC finished third for the night. Among adults 18 to 49, CBS's premiere of ''Armed and Dangerous'' (8.2 million) won the 8 p.m. hour, while reruns of ''Criminal Minds'' from 9:30 to 10:30 (11.4 million) and ''CSI: New York'' at 10:30 (10.1 million) put CBS on top for the night over all. NBC ranked second for the night, as an abbreviated ''Deal or No Deal'' (11.3 million) following President Bush's speech was the night's highest rated show among adults 18 to 49. (Nielsen estimated that 42.5 million viewers tuned in for the president's speech.) On the CW, Week 2 of ''Beauty and the Geek'' (3.9 million), the third edition of the series, led the 8 p.m. hour in the network's target demographic of adults 18 to 34.  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; For ABC, No Joy From New Comedies

content.text: The return of ''American Idol'' on Tuesday delivered record ratings for Fox, as 37.3 million viewers watched the series' sixth season premiere from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. No other Fox premiere has ever garnered more total viewers; among adults 18 to 49, it tied the 1997 ''X-Files'' season debut. For the night, Fox outdrew CBS, NBC, ABC, and the CW combined by 78 percent in the 18-to-49 demographic. CBS was second over all, buoyed by ''NCIS'' at 8 (15.9 million). NBC ranked third as ''Law and Order: Special Victims Unit'' led at 10 (14.1 million). On Friday, the Disney Channel posted its second-most-watched day on record as ''Jump In!'' with Corbin Bleu (''High School Musical'') and Keke Palmer (''Akeelah and the Bee''), drew 8.2 million viewers, the most for a Disney Channel original movie. Following it, 7.6 million viewers tuned in for the premiere of ''Cory in the House,'' the best start for a Disney series.  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Sets Fox Record

content.text: Day Two of the ''American Idol'' premiere was just as dominant as the first, as the Wednesday edition garnered 36.9 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. Declining just a half-million viewers from its record Tuesday start, the second night of ''Idol'' gave Fox one of its highest-rated Wednesdays ever. For the night, Fox once again trounced its competition, faring 79 percent better among adults 18 to 49 than NBC, ABC, CBS and CW combined. CBS was No. 2 for the night, as ''Criminal Minds'' at 9 (13.4 million) and ''CSI: New York'' at 10 (13.7 million) drew solid audiences. CBS's ''Armed and Famous'' (6.1 million) finished third in the 8 p.m. hour, behind two episodes of ''According to Jim'' on ABC (6.9 million).  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; Fox Dominates a Second Night

content.text: An obituary on Saturday about Denny Doherty, a founding member of the folk-pop band the Mamas and the Papas, misstated the name of the television network that later produced his popular television show, ''Theodore Tugboat.'' It is the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, not the Canadian Broadcasting Company.
content.title: Corrections

content.text: The latest day-in-the-life of the counterterrorism agent Jack Bauer (Kiefer Sutherland) on ''24'' got off to a solid start in the ratings on Sunday and Monday, but opposite heavy competition Fox finished both nights in second place. According to Nielsen's estimates, the Day 6 debut earned 15.7 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m. Sunday, a slight decline over its year-ago season premiere (16.2 million). However, Monday's two-hour second installment also drew 15.7 million viewers, a modest improvement over the fifth season's second episode (14.9 million). CBS was No. 1 on Sunday, benefiting from an overrun of its N.F.L. playoffs coverage, followed by an interview with President Bush on ''60 Minutes'' at approximately 8:30 (17.2 million). ABC's ''Desperate Housewives'' (16.7 million) also outdrew ''24'' during the 9 p.m. hour Sunday. On Monday, NBC's telecast of the 64th annual Golden Globes led during every half-hour of the night and averaged 20 million viewers over all, that award show's highest ratings in three years. NBC fared less well Sunday as the second week of ''Grease: You're the One That I Want'' at 8 (8.2 million) and ''The Apprentice'' at 9 (7.3 million) fell to fourth place.  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; Quick Start for Nimble Jack

content.text: After a six-week hiatus, the return of NBC's ''Heroes'' Monday relegated Fox's ''24'' to second place in the 9 p.m. ratings. According to Nielsen's estimates, ''Heroes'' led ''24'' by 20 percent among adults 18 to 49, and had 14.8 million viewers, compared to 14.4 million for ''24.'' NBC ranked first for the night in the 18-to-49 set as its game show ''Deal or No Deal'' (17.6 million) easily won the 8 p.m. hour over Fox's ''Prison Break,'' which drew a season-high of 9.9 million viewers. Despite ranking third for the night among adults 18 to 49, CBS managed to finish first in total viewers. Its sitcom ''Two and a Half Men'' outdrew ''Heroes'' and ''24'' in its half-hour at 9 (16.1 million), while ''CSI: Miami'' (18.7 million) dominated the 10 p.m. hour. ABC was fourth over all.  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; 'Heroes' Holds Off '24'

content.text: As New York City's aspiring singers descended upon ''American Idol'' on Wednesday, the episode drew 33.6 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates, giving Fox another commanding ratings victory on the night. CBS was a distant second in total viewers, as ''CSI: New York'' (13.4 million) led the 10 o'clock hour. CBS's new reality show, ''Armed and Famous'' (4.7 million), sank to fourth place at 8. NBC edged out CBS in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic for the night, winning second place behind Fox with the help of ''Deal or No Deal'' at 9 (10.1 million). Nielsen also estimated that the State of the Union address, carried live on Tuesday by nine national broadcast and cable networks, drew almost four million viewers more than President Bush's 2006 address (45.5 million, compared with 41.7 million). Despite the overall increase, the Fox News channel drew its smallest audience for a State of the Union by Mr. Bush, off nearly two million viewers from a year ago (4.6 million, compared with 6.5 million). Fox News's coverage remained first among cable channels, but No. 2 CNN saw a slight increase (to 2.4 million from 2.2 million) and No. 3 MSNBC's audience more than doubled, to 1.6 million viewers from 707,000.  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; Local Talent Buoys 'Idol'

content.text: A report in the Extra Time soccer roundup last Wednesday about reaction to the star player David Beckham's decision to leave Real Madrid for the Los Angeles Galaxy misstated the given name of Real Madrid's president. He is Ramón Calderón, not Raúl.
content.title: Corrections

content.text: A double-header of ''House'' made Fox the ratings victor on Tuesday. According to Nielsen's estimates, the 9 p.m. episode, in which Dr. House (Hugh Laurie) managed to save himself from jail time, was the highest-rated show of the night, drawing 17.8 million viewers. It followed an 8 p.m. repeat of ''House'' (9 million), which also ranked first in its time slot among adults 18 to 49, even as a rerun of CBS's ''NCIS'' at 8 outdrew it in total viewers (12.8 million). NBC led the 10 p.m. hour with ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (14.5 million) and edged out CBS for second place for the night. NBC earned modest ratings successes earlier in the night with ''Dateline'' at 8 (9.6 million) and ''Law & Order: Criminal Intent'' at 9 (11.9 million). From 9 to 11, CBS's coverage of the 33rd Annual People's Choice Awards, with Queen Latifah as host, drew 11.3 million viewers, a slight increase from the show's ratings a year ago. ABC was fourth for the night as ''Big Day'' continued to garner small audiences at 9 (4.4 million) and 9:30 (4 million).  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; 'House' Piles Up Numbers

content.text: On the night of President Bush's State of the Union address, the ''American Idol'' judges kicked off prime time in Memphis with imposing ratings as usual. According to Nielsen's estimates, which do not account for time zone discrepancies due to interruptions for the president's live speech, the series yielded 31.2 million viewers in the 8 p.m. hour Tuesday, significantly ahead of second place ''NCIS'' on CBS (14.3 million). As a result, Fox retained a substantial lead going into State of the Union programming at 9. Ratings for the 49-minute address weren't immediately available, but preliminary approximations show Fox's coverage on top, followed by NBC and CBS in a close race for second, and ABC in fourth. On Sunday, ''Ocean's Deadliest,'' the documentary Steve Irwin was filming when he was killed, attracted 3.2 million viewers. It was carried on two cable channels, Discovery (1.7 million) and Animal Planet (1.5 million), from 8 p.m. to 9:30.  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' and President Win for Fox

content.text: An obituary on Jan. 12 about the producer and writer Steve Krantz misspelled the surname of his surviving sister. She is Sunny Onish, not Ornish.
content.title: Corrections

content.text: A Sports of The Times column on Wednesday, about Muhammad Ali's 65th birthday, rendered incorrectly an antiwar quotation from him in the 1960s. He said, ''I ain't got no quarrel with them Vietcong'' -- not ''I got nothin' against them Vietcong.''
content.title: Corrections

content.text: An obituary on Wednesday about Iwao Takamoto, the artist who created Scooby-Doo and other cartoon characters, in some copies misstated the day that he died. It was Monday, not last Tuesday.
content.title: Corrections

content.text: With the holiday season ended, NBC returned to original programming on Tuesday, winning the night in total viewers for the first time this season. According to Nielsen's estimate, NBC's ''Law & Order: Criminal Intent'' garnered 13.4 million viewers at 9 p.m., the show's largest audience in more than a year. NBC also dominated the 10 p.m. hour with ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (15.1 million), which drew the night's highest ratings. NBC's ''Dateline'' (9.5 million) ranked second in the 8 p.m. hour. Meanwhile Orange Bowl coverage of Louisville's win over Wake Forest appeared to give Fox an edge over CBS for No. 2 for the night. The game averaged 10.6 million viewers according to time-zone adjusted estimates. CBS received relatively strong ratings for repeats of ''NCIS'' at 8 (13 million) and ''The Unit'' at 9 (9.1 million), but a rerun of ''Numb3rs,'' which is usually broadcast on Fridays, earned 6.7 million viewers at 10. ABC finished fourth with repeats of ''America's Funniest Home Videos'' at 8 (8.1 million) and ''Boston Legal'' at 10 (5 million), as well as two new episodes of ''Big Day'' at 9 (5.2 million) and 9:30 (4.8 million).  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; NBC's Happy New Year

content.text: The byline was omitted from the Dec. 17 public editor column. The column was by Byron Calame.
content.title: Correction

content.text: An article about the Chevrolet Volt electric car on Jan. 7 gave the incorrect Web site of the California Cars Initiative, an advocate of such cars. It is CalCars.org, not Calcars.com.
content.title: Correction

content.text: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about layoffs at The Philadelphia Inquirer referred incorrectly to the newspaper's bureaus during the 1980s. The paper had a total of about 15 national and foreign bureaus; it did not have 15 foreign bureaus
content.title: Corrections

content.text: With ABC showing repeats, CBS easily drew the most viewers in every hour on Sunday night, according to Nielsen's estimates. ''Cold Case,'' the night's most-watched program, garnered 15.1 million viewers at 8 p.m. It was preceded by ''60 Minutes'' at 7 (14.3 million), and followed by the Hallmark Hall of Fame movie ''The Valley of Light,'' with Chris Klein, which attracted 14.7 million viewers from 9 to 11. ABC won the night among adults 18 to 49 and finished second in total viewers. NBC ranked third, as the first live edition of ''Grease: You're the One That I Want'' posted the series's lowest rating yet, averaging 7.3 million viewers from 7 to 9 p.m. Following it ''The Apprentice'' improved over its week-ago performance, drawing 8.4 million viewers and finishing No. 2 in the 9 p.m. hour among adults 18 to 49.  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; 'Cold Case' Carries the Night for CBS

content.text: Fiesta Bowl coverage of Boise State's dramatic overtime victory over Oklahoma on Monday gave Fox a ratings victory for the night, but CBS's lineup of repeats trailed close behind. According to Nielsen's preliminary estimates, which do not account for discrepancies across time zones, approximately 14 million viewers tuned in during prime-time hours to watch the game, which kicked off at 8:53 p.m. and lasted until 12:51 a.m. CBS was second for the night in total viewers, getting a boost at 9 from ''Two and a Half Men'' (12.1 million) and at 10 from ''CSI: Miami'' (12.1 million). Among adults 18 to 49, ABC appeared to edge out CBS for second place, dominating the 8 p.m. hour because of an overrun of its afternoon football coverage of the Rose Bowl. Later in the night, however, repeats of ABC's ''Supernanny'' at 9 (6.7 million) and 10 (6.9 million) ranked a distant third. NBC was fourth over all with a marathon of ''Heroes'' repeats, which drew 5.5 million viewers at 8, 5.2 million at 9 and 4.6 million at 10.  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; Gridiron Drama Makes Fox a Winner

content.text: A television review in Weekend on Jan. 5 about the new reality show ''Living With Ed,'' on HGTV, misidentified the car that Ed Begley Jr. drives. It is a Toyota converted to run on electricity, not a Volkswagen.
content.title: Corrections

content.text: When Comedy Central's Stephen Colbert, who plays a caricature of a self-involved conservative pundit on ''The Colbert Report,'' exchanged guest stints Thursday with Bill O'Reilly, the Fox News host whom Mr. Colbert affectionately calls ''Papa Bear,'' ratings for both shows surged. According to Nielsen, Mr. O'Reilly's appearance helped ''The Colbert Report'' garner 1.7 million viewers at 11:30 p.m., a record high in that show's 15-month history. Earlier in the night, from 8 to 9 p.m., ''The O'Reilly Factor'' saw its ratings soar 46 percent over its fourth-quarter average last year, to nearly 3 million viewers. Among ''Factor'' viewers ages 25 to 54, a demographic in which Mr. Colbert's show regularly draws more viewers, the increase was even more pronounced. Mr. O'Reilly's show improved from an average of 450,000 viewers in that age group to 750,000.  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; Colbert-O'Reilly Swap Offers Mutual Benefits

content.text: A report last Sunday about the Seabring-Ebel marriage misspelled the bride's given name. She is Courtenay Cooper Seabring, not Courtney.
content.title: Correction

content.text: An article in Business Day on Monday about a dispute between Wendy P. McCaw, the owner of The Santa Barbara News-Press in California and the newsroom staff misspelled the name of the city where Don Murphy, the former manager editor of the paper, has taken a job. It is San Luis Obispo, not San Louis Obispo. The credit for a picture of Ms. McCaw misstated the given name of the photographer. He is Paul Wellman, not Paula.
content.title: Corrections

content.text: A report in the World Business Briefing column last Thursday about the start up of Ironshore Insurance in Bermuda carried an incorrect credit. It was by Bloomberg News, not The Associated Press.
content.title: Corrections

content.text: Introduced on Sunday: Lincoln MKR design study  Is it real?: This car isn't, but its design themes and powertrains are  destined for future Lincolns.  What's the point? Lincoln has fallen desperately behind the luxury leaders,  and this dramatic chrome-face concept shows Lincoln reasserting its American roots.  What they said: ''We're referring to the past without repeating it,'' Peter Horbury, Ford's director of design for the Americas, said.  What they didn't say: In following the lead of the Mercedes-Benz CLS by styling a four-door sedan to look like a sexy coupe, Lincoln is also distancing itself from retro designs that lacked new ideas.  What makes it tick? Behind its grinning mug -- a nod to the '41 Lincoln Continental Cabriolet -- there's a 415-horsepower 3.5-liter V-6 with direct fuel injection and two turbochargers. The engine is E85 ethanol-ready, and Ford claims better fuel economy than a comparably powerful V-8.  How much, how soon?: The engine is part of a new ''TwinForce'' family that should begin powering Ford and Lincoln models by about 2009.  How's it look?: A shot of design adrenaline that -- if actually administered  to showroom models -- could wake Lincoln from its long coma.
content.title: In the MKR, Just a Hint of Lincoln's Past

content.text: Original episodes and reruns of ''The Sopranos'' have been running on HBO since 1999 and are on DVD. But that didn't stop 4.3 million viewers from watching the basic-cable premiere of the series's first episode on Wednesday night on A&E, according to Nielsen estimates released by the channel. A&E, which is planning to run two episodes of the series each Wednesday night (edited for language, violence and nudity), said its debut showing was well above its prime-time average last year (by more than 200 percent) and good enough to beat the ratings of any other advertiser-supported cable channel that night.  JACQUES STEINBERG
content.title: Arts, Briefly; Tony, We Love You

content.text: The Bowl Championship Series title game ended badly for the top-ranked Ohio State Buckeyes on Monday, but it was a huge success for the Fox television network. According to Nielsen's time-zone-adjusted estimates, the football game dominated in every half-hour of the night, attracting 28.7 million viewers. Among adults 18 to 49, Fox posted its highest-rated Monday in three years. CBS ranked second for the night, aided by ''CSI: Miami'' at 10 (15.9 million) and its comedies in the 9 p.m. hour, ''Two and a Half Men'' (14.8 million) and ''The New Adventures of Old Christine'' (12.2 million). NBC was No. 2 in the 8 o'clock hour with ''Deal or No Deal'' (14 million), but its two repeats of ''Heroes'' finished last at 9 (5.7 million) and 10 (4.1 million). ABC's line-up of ''Wife Swap'' at 8 (8 million), ''Supernanny'' at 9 (8.1 million) and ''What About Brian'' at 10 (4.7 million) once again put the network in fourth place for the night in total viewers, but among adults 18 to 49, NBC lagged slightly behind it.  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; Bowl Game Delivers for Fox

content.text: Introduced on Monday:Honda Accord Coupe Concept  Is it real? Some automakers' concepts are nothing but car teases; Honda, bless them, moves its concepts swiftly to showrooms with few changes. Expect the 2008 Accord coupe to strongly resemble this sweet-looking machine.  What's the point? Coupes are staging a comeback, and Honda wants its two-door Accord to lure a good chunk of under-30 buyers. Vastly more extroverted than the previous Accord coupe, the new model harvests styling cues from several of its two-door competitors -- including Nissan and Infiniti.  What they said: Honda executives extolled the Accord's three decades of excellence, but the press conferences' choice of musical accompaniment may have summed up the new model best: ''I'll Bet You Look Good on the Dance Floor,'' by the Arctic Monkeys.  What they didn't say: Compelling new coupes like this Accord, and its competitors from Ford, Scion and Nissan, will solidify the Toyota Solara's position as the segment's maiden aunt. The pressure will be on Toyota to swap Solara's flannel-petticoat exterior for something more silken and sexy.  What makes it tick? Honda is being coy on particulars, but the eighth-generation Accord coupe and sedan will certainly continue to offer four- and six-cylinder engines.  How much, how soon? The Accord coupe and sedan go on sale in the fall, probably starting below $20,000 and topping $30,000 for loaded versions.  How's it look? Finally, not like the Accord sedan.
content.title: Accord Falls Far From the Tree

content.text: With the best ratings for an American Football Conference championship game in 10 years, CBS's coverage of the Indianapolis Colts' victory over the New England Patriots on Sunday outdrew even last week's ''American Idol'' premiere telecasts to usurp the title of highest-rated program of the 2006-7 television season. According to Nielsen's estimates, which do not account for discrepancies across time zones, the game averaged approximately 43 million viewers for the night. ABC's ''Desperate Housewives'' was the second-most-watched show on Sunday, delivering a much-reduced 17.1 million viewers at 9. ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' at 8 (12.6 million) and ''Brothers & Sisters'' at 10 (11.9 million) helped ABC secure a distant but respectable second-place finish for the night. NBC was third over all, as ratings for Week 3 of its reality shows ''Grease: You're the One That I Want'' at 8 (8.1 million) and ''The Apprentice'' at 9 (6.9 million) remained steady after falling in the shows' second week.  BENJAMIN TOFF
content.title: Arts, Briefly; Football Playoff Piles Up Record Ratings

content.text: The credit for pictures last Monday with the continuation of a front-page article about a whooping cough scare at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center omitted the photographer's surname. He is Jon Gilbert Fox.
content.title: Corrections
